clinical_study.brief_title: Does Instruction on Cognitive Aid Use Improve Performance and Retention of Skills?
clinical_study.official_title: Does Instruction on Cognitive Aid Use Improve Performance and Retention of Skills? A Simulation Based Randomized Controlled Trial

collaborator.agency: The Academy for Innovation in Medical Education
The Ottawa Hospital Academic Medical Association

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether formal instruction on the use of cognitive aids in managing a crisis will result in better longterm retention of knowledge and skills. In particular, this study examines the impact of cognitive aid teaching on the Advanced Cardiac Life Support course.

primary_outcome.description: Simulated scenarios will be videotaped. These will be scored according to the ACLS megacode testing checklist by trained video raters

secondary_outcome.description: Simulated Scenarios will be videotaped. Videos will be scored by trained raters according to the validated Anesthesia Nontechnical Skills Scale.

clinical_study.condition: Long-term Retention of Advanced Cardiac Life Support Skills

arm_group.description: This group gets a simulation based ACLS refresher as treatment, but no access to cognitive aids for any of the tests.

This group receives a standard Simulation based ACLS refresher as the intervention, like the control group. No mention is made of Cognitive Aids in the teaching, but they are available during the post-test and retention post-test.
This group receives Cognitive Aid based teaching as the intervention. They also have access to cognitive aids for post-test and retention post-test

intervention.intervention_name: Standard Simulation Based ACLS Refresher Teaching
intervention.description: 45min-1 hour time. 15 minutes didactic review of 2010 ACLS guidelines followed by practice simulated megacodes

intervention.intervention_name: Cognitive Aid based ACLS Refresher training
intervention.description: 45min-1 hour time. 15 minutes didactic review of 2010 ACLS guidelines followed by simulated ACLS megacode practice focused on the use of Cognitive Aids to guide management.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Post-graduate Medical trainee in departments of Anesthesia, Emergency Medicine, Critical Care, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine
- Has taken ACLS Course at least once
Exclusion Criteria:
- Never taken ACLS Course
